coredata.dc:title: Assessment of the pre-combustion carbon capture contribution into sustainable development goals SDGs using novel indicators
coredata.dc:creator: Olabi, A.G.
Obaideen, Khaled
Elsaid, Khaled
Wilberforce, Tabbi
Sayed, Enas Taha
Maghrabie, Hussein M.
Abdelkareem, Mohammad Ali
coredata.dc:description: The rapid progress in the global population and technical advances have resulted in exponential growth in the use of fossil fuels. These are not only limited in resources but also have a severe environmental impact. The accumulation of greenhouse gases (GHGs), more specifically carbon emissions, in the environment has resulted in severe health issues and climate changes. The Paris Climate Agreement calls for restricting global warming to only 1.5 °C by 2050 relative to the pre-industrial era. This requires reducing global GHGs emissions as soon and as much as possible. Massive efforts are being put into minimizing GHG emissions, such as using renewable energy resources and/or using carbon capture technologies (CCT). In this study, different CCTs were introduced, focusing on the pre-combustion as a promising CCT approach. In this work, the role of CCT in realizing the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) was thoroughly analyzed and discussed. A total of 87 indicators were developed to measure and analyze the contribution of CCT to achieving the different SDGs. The focus given to the role of the pre-combustion CCT in achieving SDGs is being elaborated. The indicators and analysis covered the economic, environmental, and social pillars of sustainable development. It was found that CCT contributes well to all 17 SDGs, with core and substantial contributions to SDG-7 of "Affordable and clean energy", and ultimately SDG-13 of "Climate action". The developed indicators would work as a guideline for the different players to ensure that CCT is fully adhering the SDGs principles. The proposed indicators have nine main benefits, i.e., assist in the achievement of the SDGs, providing information for the decision-makers, enhance and benchmark sustainability performance, improve risk management, enhance data management and reporting practices, improve resource allocation and reduce the expenses, improve environmental performance, reduce social impact, and improve communications with stakeholder. Moreover, the different barriers facing the CCT were presented.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The rapid progress in the global population and technical advances have resulted in exponential growth in the use of fossil fuels. These are not only limited in resources but also have a severe environmental impact. The accumulation of greenhouse gases (GHGs), more specifically carbon emissions, in the environment has resulted in severe health issues and climate changes. The Paris Climate Agreement calls for restricting global warming to only 1.5 °C by 2050 relative to the pre-industrial era. This requires reducing global GHGs emissions as soon and as much as possible. Massive efforts are being put into minimizing GHG emissions, such as using renewable energy resources and/or using carbon capture technologies (CCT). In this study, different CCTs were introduced, focusing on the pre-combustion as a promising CCT approach. In this work, the role of CCT in realizing the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) was thoroughly analyzed and discussed. A total of 87 indicators were developed to measure and analyze the contribution of CCT to achieving the different SDGs. The focus given to the role of the pre-combustion CCT in achieving SDGs is being elaborated. The indicators and analysis covered the economic, environmental, and social pillars of sustainable development. It was found that CCT contributes well to all 17 SDGs, with core and substantial contributions to SDG-7 of "Affordable and clean energy", and ultimately SDG-13 of "Climate action". The developed indicators would work as a guideline for the different players to ensure that CCT is fully adhering the SDGs principles. The proposed indicators have nine main benefits, i.e., assist in the achievement of the SDGs, providing information for the decision-makers, enhance and benchmark sustainability performance, improve risk management, enhance data management and reporting practices, improve resource allocation and reduce the expenses, improve environmental performance, reduce social impact, and improve communications with stakeholder. Moreover, the different barriers facing the CCT were presented.

ce:section.ce:para: Global carbon emissions from fossil commodities have increased by 2.7% annually over the last decade, and are currently 60% higher than 1990 levels, the Kyoto Protocol's reference year [1,2]. CO2 levels, on the other hand, are required to be cut by at least half to save global surface temperatures from rising by more than 2 °C by 2050 [3]. Carbon capture (CC), followed by storage or utilization (CCS or CCU) are only two of the several solutions being explored around the planet to further accomplish this aim of combating climate change [4–6]. Meanwhile, CCS is also one of the promising technologies that could assist in attaining the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) [7–9]. CCS poses a host of technological and economic challenges that must be addressed for its wide implementation. One of the most significant economic barriers is the high cost, hence making it unprofitable, as it necessitates a significant capital expenditure [10]. Technically, CO2 leakage rates from geological formations are unknown. Additionally, in some countries, CCS might not be feasible, as such formations have low storage capacity or are inaccessible, resulting in higher shipping and injection costs, as in the case of the United Kingdom UK, Norway, Singapore, Brazil, and India [10,11].

CCU is a similar alternative that has increasingly gained traction across the globe because it can convert emitted CO2 into useful chemicals and fuels, while still helping to mitigate climate change. CCU has the benefit over CCS in that CO2 is used as feedstock and is typically a lucrative operation when goods may be exported [10]. CO2 also has the advantages of being a “renewable” feedstock and non-toxic when compared to traditional petrochemical feedstocks, despite being of low quality [12]. Even though CO2 conversion to different materials is energy-intensive, the prospect of ensuring a reliable supply of fuels and chemicals can be a powerful driver for CCU [10,12]. Nonetheless, existing global chemical production is inadequate to sequester carbon emissions enough to contribute substantially to achieving carbon mitigation goals. Furthermore, CCU often delays rather than eliminates CO2 pollution over the lengthy timescales needed to combat climate change. Other mitigation considerations, such as environmental risks, must be addressed in addition to the above factors before the implementation of CCS/CCU. This is vital to ensure that the mitigation of climate change does result in any other environmental concerns. It's also important to measure the effects throughout a life cycle to prevent moving environmental pressures from one point to another.

The United Nations, in 2015, set seventeen sustainable development goals (SDGs), as shown in Fig. 1 , to be achieved by 2030 in the path of achieving peace and prosperity for both human and Earth (https://sdgs.un.org/goals). The goals are to large extent interconnected, as such, efforts toward achieving a certain goal help partially in achieving some of the other goals as well.

The SDGs aims are not to only end poverty and hunger, but also to work towards saving the planet and promoting the well-being and health of individuals. The main strategy of the UN for the protection of the planet is by supporting the present and future needs of generations. The UN, with the support of 193 member states focuses on the preservation of resources for the use of future generations.The world is in a state of climatic emergency, as such, SDGs play a central role in producing clean and affordable energy for saving life on both sea and land-hence taking demonstrable actions [13]. CCS can be considered as an extremely reliable, secure as well as a sustainable approach for reducing the effects of global warming [14].

This work presents a detailed novel analysis of various CC technologies, with a focus on pre-combustion, in relation to SDGs achievement. The work describes and discusses the different carbon capture technologies (CCTs) in terms of working principle and performance, comparing different CCTs for their different advantages and disadvantages. The work then thoroughly discusses the contribution of CCT in achieving SDGs. The work is then expanded to develop a set of novel indicators relating CCT contribution toward the achievement of UN-SDGs. The developed indicators are set with the ultimate objective to ensure that all possible trade-off impacts of the pre-combustion CC-based projects with all SDGs have been reduced or even eliminated, as well as providing a set of balance between the three pillars of sustainable development, i.e., economic, environmental, and social. This work is opening a new opportunity to the different engineering disciplines through integrating sustainability within their project with the aim to achieve the SDGs. Furthermore, the different barriers facing the CCTs as well as the role of the CCT in circular economy and related SDGs were elaborated.

Several commercially accessible and commonly used technologies for capturing CO2 from a gaseous mixture already exist today, usually as a purification stage in many industrial activities, mostly in oil and gas processing [15,16]. The process selection is usually based on the chemical and physical conditions of the gaseous stream being processed (flowrate, pressure, temperature, CO2 concentration, impurities present,..etc.). CC processes have been widely used to remove CO2 in natural gas processing, hydrogen and ammonia production, and many other industrial processes. However, captured carbon is commonly emitted into the atmosphere, or less often utilized for the production of chemicals as in the case of urea, i.e., reacting CO2 with ammonia to produce urea [17]. Fig. 2 shows the different CCS and CCU options from carbon source to carbon sink.

Carbon emissions have also been partially retrieved from flue gases emitted by coal- or natural gas-fired power plants. The CO2 is captured and marketed as a product to local businesses, including food processing facilities. Even so, very little volumes of CO2 are required to produce such consumer goods around the planet, and almost all of them are easily released into the environment (as in the case of carbonated drinks). Since the majority of anthropogenic CO2 is generated in the flue gas from fossil fuel combustion, CCTs, as shown in Fig. 3 , are categorized as either post-combustion or pre-combustion [18,19]. The third approach, known as oxy-combustion or oxyfuel, does not necessitate the use of a CO2 capture system. While certain manufacturing processes use oxy-combustion, this approach is still in the early stages and is not yet viable for power plants. The main aim of CCTs is to produce a CO2 stream to be sequestered, either by storage in geological formations, CCS, or utilize CCU [19]. In CCS, CO2 is injected deep underground at high pressures, to then be easily transported and pumped via pipeline.

As the name suggests, carbon emissions are captured from combustion flue gases. Currently, power plants produce a huge portion of the global carbon emissions [20,21]. Fig. 4 shows a typical scheme of post-combustion CC, as applied to flue gas from a power plant using the absorption process. The flue gases are mostly: nitrogen 67–77 vol%, originally present in combustion air at 79 vol%, followed by carbon dioxide 8–14 vol%, water vapor 8–20 vol%, and oxygen 2–5 vol% based on fuel type, i.e. coal or natural gas [22,23]. In addition to some impurities such as sulfur oxides SOx (depending on the sulfur impurities in the fuel), nitrogen oxides NOx (from oxidation of nitrogen present in air), and particulate matter PM (such as soot from coal). To satisfy relevant pollution control measures requirements, these species including mercury must be eliminated, to ensure an adequately clean gas stream for subsequent CO2 capture.

The most efficient CCT for the flue gas of power plants in general, and pulverized coal (PC) power plants, in particular, is chemisorption by monoethanolamine (MEA) in the amine absorption process. The amine process captures normally 85–90% of the CO2 in the flue gas stream. The CO2-rich amine is then heated to release CO2 and recycle CO2-lean amine [24]. The CO2 is then compressed and piped for CCS or CCU, while the regenerated amine is recycled back.

Chemical absorption of CO2 using amines has several advantages, including: high efficiency, cheap technology, and maturity [24], as shown in Fig. 4. Despite these merits, chemical absorption using amines has been shown to not offer an appealing option for CO2 separation from flue gases on a global scale [25]. In addition to the CO2 emissions associated with the amines' manufacturing process, there are many disadvantages to using amines as absorption solvents, including high toxicity, corrosiveness, degradability, and volatility [26], as well as the significant energy expenditure needed to regenerate the solvent and recover the CO2 [25]. The addition of enzymes or other catalysts may help to mitigate this impact by increasing the rate at which the reaction occurs [27]. One of the CCT is enzyme-enhanced CCS, namely the use of carbonic anhydrase (CA). Enzymes are advantageous in such processes because they speed up the reaction rate, which is particularly important for bicarbonate-forming solvents [28–31]. The enzyme CA is responsible for the hydration of CO2 into bicarbonate (Reaction 1).

CA-promoted aqueous solvents exhibit substantial increases in CO2 absorption rate, as these enzymes catalyze the rate-limiting step, which is CO2 hydration [32–35]. There are several CO2 capture industrial operations that use CA to activate a number of solvents.
Free enzyme

When Na2CO3 solutions are boosted with 0.5 mg/mL of CA, the absorption rate of the solution may rise by a factor of 7.6 [36]. The findings of modelling studies also support the usage of this solvent, as the packing height may decrease by a factor of 12 in the case of using CA of 0.5 mg/mL, and decreased by a factor of 24 when employing CA of 1 mg/mL [37]. The previously mentioned examples only examined free CA, which is usually regarded as the top limit when immobilization is taken into consideration. Gladis et al. [38] investigated the effect of CA addition on CO2 absorption in a wetted wall column. Results demonstrated that the CA significantly improved the CO2 absorption in case of MEDA “N-methyl-diethanolamine” and K2CO3, while CA had a moderate effect and no effect with AMP “2-amino-2-methyl-1-propanol” and MEA “monoethanolamine”, respectively. The authors showed that the concentration of the CA and the operating temperature depend on the type and concentration of the solvent.

In order to get an enhancement factor that is as similarly feasible to the one achieved with a free enzyme, the method by which the three phases flue gas, solvent, and solid catalyst are brought into contact is very important. In the following sections, we will discuss the various configurations for post-combustion CO2 collection, based on immobilized CA increased absorption.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Static device; packed-columns, scrubbers and bubble columns
ce:section.ce:para: As the flue gas and solvent are circulated through a packed column, a high surface packing material is used to bring the two phases, the flue gas and the solvent, into contact (Fig. 4). The packing's primary aim is to maintain excellent contact between the two phases, while preventing phase coalescence. Column packing may be utilized as a CA carrier for bioaccelerated CO2 absorption in a variety of applications. Several studies have been carried to investigate CO2 absorption using CA immobilized on washcoat [39], in the form of beads [40,41], on the surface of steel matrix [42], or polyurethane foam materials [43]. In general, the immobilization of the CA resulted in significant decrease of the CA loading. However, lower CO2 absorption capacity was observed compared to the free enzyme. The examples above demonstrate that in order to fully exploit the catalytic potential of CA, i.e., to achieve an enhancement factor comparable to that of free enzyme, it is necessary to reduce the mass transfer resistance associated with CO2 transport from interface to enzyme active site to an acceptable level. Instead of immobilizing the enzyme in/on the packing material, it is possible to immobilize it in/on flowable microparticles that create a slurry in order to enhance mass transfer and fully utilize the catalytic potential of CA [44–47].

A more sophisticated bioreactor design was suggested, which is based on the idea of process fluid dynamic intensification [48]. The use of devices such as rotating bed or rotating disc reactors, which have a high rotational speed, result in better phase dispersion and a thinner liquid film thickness as opposed to conventional devices. As a result, significant gains in mass transfer are achieved, while the size of this equipment is reduced when compared to traditional columns. When it comes to improving the resistance to enzyme deactivation under mechanical loads and moving gas–liquid interfaces, immobilizing enzymes may be a useful option [49,50].

Essentially, a gas-liquid membrane contactor is a porous membrane that is sandwiched between the gas and liquid phases. In order to overcome the limitations of traditional packed columns in terms of gas/liquid flow flexibility, compactness, and ease of scale-up [51], membrane contactors have been suggested as an alternative to conventional packed columns [52–60].

Enzymes are “fragile” molecules that can only function under a certain set of circumstances (temperature, pH and ionic strength). As a result of their tiny size (the average CA particle size is 5 × 4x4 nm3 [61]), they are difficult to collect and recycle [62,63]. CA would be dissolved in the solvent in the case of CO2 capture through absorption. Due to the high temperatures needed in the stripper, in the event of thermal desorption of CO2, the enzyme may be rendered inactive. It is possible that high ionic strength and pH, which occur when the saturated solvent is delivered to a crystallization unit, may result in enzyme deactivation if CO2 is retrieved in the form of carbonate/bicarbonate crystals. It is as a result of this that enzymes immobilized in industry are very common [64,65]. There are many immobilisation methods available, each with their own set of advantages and disadvantages [28,66]. The thermal stability of the enzymes (during stripping process) is another issue that challenges the application of enzymatic CC. Gundersen et al. [67] proposed ultrafiltration membrane as a promising method for decreasing the deactivation of the enzymes during long term operation. Also, CA derived from thermophilic organisms is especially intriguing, due to its resilience to high temperatures [68,69].

In oxy-combustion CCT, oxygen O2 is used, instead of air, for combustion. This removes a significant portion of nitrogen N2 present in conventional flue gas, i.e., 67–77 vol %, making it mostly CO2, H2O, and O2, and some other impurities which are removed [70]. Cooling and compressing the flue gas is then the easiest way to remove water vapor, leaving almost pure CO2 for CCS/CCU, as seen in Fig. 5 . The main benefit of oxyfuel is that it eliminates the need for a complex CC process, however, an air separation unit (ASU) is needed to provide O2, and present the main cost component of oxyfuel CCT. However, flue gas temperature is much higher in the case of oxyfuel, allowing partial recycling of flue gas stream for heat recovery, hence higher energy efficiency.

In pre-combustion, the fuel is partially combusted producing CO2/CO and H2, i.e., partial oxidation, as in syngas production (mixture of CO and H2). Later, H2 is separated from CO2 by physical or chemical means and used as fuel with an ultimate combustion product of water. Fig. 6 illustrates the scheme of a pre-combustion CCT utilizing pressure swing absorption and stripping. While pre-combustion CCT is very effective for mitigating pollution, the total cost of the plant is usually higher, with reduced overall performance. Chemical and physical absorbents are the two types of absorbents that are widely used for CC. Chemical absorbents react with CO2 forming products, as in the case of carbonate/bicarbonate, and hydroxide solutions, thereby highly stabilizing CO2 [71]. However, this is associated with energy requirements for regeneration, which raises the plant capital expenditure.

Physical solvents absorb CO2 favorably at high pressures and low temperatures [72,73]. Many aqueous solutions, including polypropylene carbonate [74], methanol (Rectisol) [75], dimethyl ether polyethylene glycol DMEPEG (Selexol), and N-methyl-2-pyrollidone (Purisol) [76,77], have been utilized on a commercial scale for CCT. Physical absorbents strip out the absorbed gases by pressure swing, releasing pressure, and mild heating, hence reducing the energy consumption relative to chemical absorbents, where absorbent regeneration requires higher energy for bond breakage. The CO2 solubility, or absorption affinity, and physical propoerties (density, viscosity, vapor pressure,..) of the absorbent are crucial for the proper selection of the physical absorbent. Low mass transfer, validity up to low-temperature, reactive solvents, and economic inadequacy to attain high commodity gas purity are some of the drawbacks of industrial physical solvents. Ionic liquids have been studied as a physical absorbent for CC in recent years, showing to be a promising substitute for physical absorbents, since they need lower energy for regeneration and have low vapor pressures [78,79].

The cost of a CC integrated power plant is evaluated by many factors, such as: location, utilities, and separation process. Auxiliary expenses include absorbent thermal recovery, absorbent pumping, and liquid and gas stream heating/cooling. For CO2 absorption, the Selexol process has lower strength, heating, and cooling energy duties than the Rectisol and MDEA processes [80]. Dave et al. achieved 90.4% CO2 absorption from syngas in a packed tower using DMEPEG [72]. The pre-combustion CCT power plant using Selexol solvent reduced carbon emissions by 90.9%, while net electric power was reduced by 145 MW [81]. Another study showed that extracting 90% of CO2 in the Selexol process resulted in a 5–7% reduction in lower heating value LHV as an indicator for the thermal efficiency [82]. Table 1 provides a simple comparison among the three CCTs.

Post-combustion CCT is generally a well-established process, however, it results in increasing the overall energy consumption by about 25–40% [83]. The post-combustion CCT generally runs at atmospheric pressure with low CO2 concentrations (<15%) and can accommodate high flue gas flowrates [84]. Despite the advantages of oxy-combustion, it is still an energy-intensive process, particularly for ASU. Pre-combustion CCT reduces energy consumption in high-pressure and low-temperature systems to ensure high performance. In pre-combustion CCT, the increase in overall energy consumption relative to no CCT is only 7–9.5% [85]. The type of process and material or reagent used to separate and capture CO2 is very crucial for the overall performance and economics of CCS [17,86,87]. Amine processes, in which CO2 is being absorbed by an alkaline amine solution have been the typical processes used in gas processing for the purification of natural gas. However, this process is both energy- and material-intensive. Accordingly, alternative materials must be assessed for their CO2 capture performance and energy consumption, as well as the costs associated with recovery. Table 2 provides a simple comparison for the merits and demerits of different CC process of absorption, adsorption and membrane separation. Meanwhile, the most commonly used materials in post/oxy/pre-combustion CCTs are summarized in Table 3 and consequently discussed. In this section, the new processes developed for CC are being thoroughly discussed.

Computer-aided modeling has been widely utilized for the evaluation of innovative CO2 capture materials. Simulations at the atomic and molecular scales have been known for their potential to contribute to the inception of new materials, or optimization of established materials quickly and at low cost [109,110]. Density Functional Theory (DFT) is a powerful tool for screening out materials that could be used for CC. Different models must be used to perform a DFT study of various materials, such as sorbents and oxygen carriers (OCs) [111,112]. The DFT energetic effects may be modified to particular operational conditions utilizing the atomistic thermodynamic models, or via molecular dynamic simulations [113,114].

Chemical looping (CL) has gotten attention recently because of its low energy requirements relative to other CC techniques [115,116]. In CL, an intermediate material acts as an oxygen carrier (OC), which undergoes oxidation by air to acquire oxygen. The OC then gives off the oxygen for fuel combustion, i.e., reduced, and the cycle of reduction/oxidation (redox) keeps repeating. There are two chemical looping schemes based on the reaction characteristics. The first approach involves the indirect burning of fuels. This is accomplished by adding OC, which decreases permanent entropy during the burning phase. Metal oxides are reduced in the first reactor (the reducer) to achieve complete oxidation of the fuel as shown in Fig. 7 (a). The reduced metal oxides are then removed to the second reactor for re-oxidation by air, completing the cycle. In the second approach, two reactors are used as well, namely a carbonator and a calciner. CaO is commonly used as a carrier, which is carbonated by CO2 to CaCO3, while CaCO3 undergoes calcination to release CO2 in the calciner, as seen in Fig. 7(b) [116].

The most desirable feature of OCs is their high reaction reactivity for redox reactions. Furthermore, high oxygen capacity, along with high thermal, mechanical, and chemical stability for long-term reliability under harsh operating pressure and temperature conditions are desired [117,118]. OCs should be cheap, easy to use, and environmentally friendly. Over the last few decades, various OC products have been experimentally researched and examined [119]. DFT has been widely used to gain insight into reaction kinetics [120]. In this area, DFT analysis has mainly been used to examine the reactivity of OCs in the redox phase. Fe-based [89,121–130] and Cu-based OCs [131–134] are commonly investigated for CL applications utilizing DFT. Although NiO-based OCs are common for CL, only a few DFT studies were present [135–137]. Other OCs have also been studied in CO and CH4 transformations, such as Mn3O4 (001) [90] and CaSO4 [138]. Mixed OCs, including various metal components such as Perovskites, have received a lot of attention as well [139–141].

N2/CO2, N2/O2, and H2/CO2 separation are essential for post/oxy/pre-combustion, respectively. These are the common applications of membranes in CC. Membranes serve as filters throughout the separation phase, permeating only specific components in a mixture while retaining other components, resulting in an enriched stream of the intended gas product. The membrane separation has shown tremendous promise in CCS because it does not necessitate large-scale investments. Also, unlike conventional solvent-based systems, which need a lot of heat to regenerate the solvent, this system uses much less energy, hence lower operating and capital expenditures. Membranes may also be configured to suit various separation processes based on their particular layout.

The permeability, as well as selectivity of a membrane, are the most critical considerations in its architecture for CC. Selectivity is the ratio of permeabilities across different gas types, while permeability is the flux of gas permeation per unit pressure. Inorganic, organic, and organic frameworks are the most common types of membranes used for CO2 capture [142]. H2-selective membranes are mostly used in the pre-combustion CCT for H2/CO2 separation [143]. Because of their possible infinite H2 selectivity, metal membranes are to some degree suitable for this kind of method [144]. Palladium (Pd) alloys have been widely studied for hydrogen purification membranes, but the main disadvantage of Pd membranes is being susceptible to H2-induced embrittlement and surface contamination [145]. Pd-alloy membranes, on the other side, can tolerate surface poisoning while preserving the attractive properties of pure Pd membranes [146,147].

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are considered promising adsorbents for CC applications and have been the subject of several studies. MOFs have strongly arranged crystal structures, with both metal nodes and organic linkers, that resemble the naturally occurring Zeolites, enabling them to have a broad spectrum of properties for several applications [148]. Because of the large variety of MOFs, due to the different metal locations and different linkers, DFT has been used for materials screening for CC applications [149–151]. MOFs are recognized for their large surface area and pore volume, making them excellent adsorbents [152]. MOFs’ physical and chemical characteristics such as pore size (tunable pore diameter and length), and functional groups, may also be customized through varying building blocks and synthesis strategies, making them highly selective adsorbents [148,153]. When it comes to material power, MOFs have a high degree of stability, for adsorbent reactivation/regeneration, while preserving the crystal structure of MOFs [154]. MOFs are attractive candidates for CC in post-combustion technologies [155–157].

Adsorption properties of CO2 selectivity, adsorption capacity, and rate are keys for finding promising CO2 adsorbents [158,159]. Borges et al. studied CC selectivity among H2, N2, CH4, and CO onto MOFs, concluding MIL-160 to be promising for CO2-selective adsorbent [160]. DFT studies were used to determine the adsorption function of CO2, finding that the Zr-metal cluster performs better [161]. DFT simulations may also be used to evaluate the impact of impurities on the CO2 adsorption phase [162]. The foregoing theoretical studies include instructions for optimizing MOFs or even developing new MOFs for CC [163–167].

Zeolites are porous crystallized aluminosilicates with exchangeable cations. Zeolites have been utilized for post/pre-combustion CC applications due to their structural cages, pores, and exchangeable cations. Zeolites are appealing for carbon adsorption due to their unique adsorption capacity and selectivity. Exchangeable cations, pore sizes, and the Si/Al ratio are essential parameters in zeolite selection for CO2 adsorption [168,169]. Adsorption affinity, capacity, rate, and selectivity of zeolites can be predicted using DFT as CO2 adsorbents [98,170–172].

Ionic liquids (ILs) are deemed attractive in many applications for the separation of standard volatile compounds [173,174]. ILs are ionic compounds with melting points well below 100 °C, and so are mostly liquid at ambient temperature. They have outstanding thermal resilience, strong solubility, and the potential to exchange ions, making them appealing for many industrial applications, including CC [175]. ILs often allow for the mixing of various ions, enabling products to be fine-tuned for even better efficiency. This means ILs can be customized for specific purposes. Because of their experimentally recorded high CC capacities and attractive chemical or physical properties, ILs have been widely explored for CC [174–176]. Molecular dynamic and DFT simulations could predict complex properties of ILs, including CO2 diffusivity at particular pressures and temperatures [177–179]. CO2 absorption also improves the viscosity and molecular mobility of ILs in heterogeneous structures [180,181]. The interactions of anions and cations of the ILs with CO2, SO2, and H2S were analyzed using DFT, indicating that for weak cation-anion interactions, ILs are more likely to associate with CO2 [182–185].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Pilot- and commercial-scale carbon capture facilities

ce:section.ce:para: Although today most CCS plants use amine processes, the early stages of CC development utilized a range of novel solvents, membranes, and sorbents. While not yet widely installed at full-scale on power plants, post-combustion CC systems were being used commercially in other industrial processes for decades, mostly for natural gas processing [186,187]. The Mitsubishi Heavy Industries KM-CDR, Fluor Econamine FG Plus, Aker Carbon Capture Just CatchTM, Lummus Kerr-McGee, HTC Purenergy Inc., and Cansolv are among the industrial amine-based processes currently in use [187]. Lummus systems use a 20% aqueous MEA solution, while Fluor systems use a 30% amine [187]. The higher amine concentrations reduces the energy consumption and equipment size, hence also reducing the capital and operating expenditure of CC. However, since amines are corrosive, higher concentrations necessitate corrosion inhibitors or costly materials of construction.

The captured carbon from gas processing has been usually vented to the environment. Currently, with the deployment of CC, such carbon emissions, along with carbon captured from power plants are being sequestered in deep geological formations. The Statoil natural gas facility in Sleipner, Norway, has been in operation since 1996 and is the world's longest-running commercial CCS plant [188,189].

Two commercial-scale pre-combustion CCT facilities are currently operational. The Selexol process at the Farmlands chemical plant in Coffeyville, Kansas, US captures and separates CO2/H2 from the gasification of petroleum coke in the IGCC power plant. More than 93% of CO2 is collected at the Coffeyville site, equivalent to about 200,000 t-CO2 annually [190]. The second is at the Dakota Gasification Company's Great Plains synfuels plant in ND, US. This one uses coal gasification to produce syngas. The plants use the methanol-based Rectisol process at an annual capacity of 3 mt-CO2. Previously, CO2 was released into the atmosphere; currently, it is compressed and sent to a Canadian oil field by a 205-mile pipeline for enhanced oil recovery. While a range of full-scale projects has been revealed, no full-scale pre-combustion CC has been implemented at a power plant to date [191]. At the pilot scale, there are currently very few pre-combustion CC plants. Two ventures at power plants in Europe, the Elcogas's Puertollano plant in Spain and Buggenum Nuon's plant in the Netherlands, are the first implementations of CC at operational power plant facilities, though on a limited scale and treating only a portion of the syngas stream [192].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Life cycle assessment of carbon capture technologies
ce:section.ce:para: A recent study looked at two coal-fired IGCC power plants, using chemical looping pre-combustion CC. In terms of performance and environmental efficiency, the two plants were assessed and compared to conventional power plants without CCS at 440–610 MWe of net electricity [193]. CC rates of 99.5 and 91.6% were obtained for Fe-based and Ca-based CL. The work's primary emphasis was on the environmental analyses of the three plants, which were undertaken using the life cycle assessment LCA technique. Following a “cradle-to-grave” approach, the analysis looked at 1) power generation; 2) upstream processes; and 3) downstream processes. The study involved the commissioning, operation, and decommissioning phases of the power plant. Eleven environmental impact categories were evaluated among the different power plants with and without CCS. Many of the metrics were addressed, including: global warming potential GWP, acidification potential AP, and eutrophication potential EP, as the most significant environmental effect indicators. Power plant with CC had the major environmental advantages of reduced GHG and GWP, but other environmental metrics such as AP and EP have increased significantly. The rise is attributable to the inclusion of certain upstream and downstream processes, as well as the additional material and energy utilized in the CC unit.

The environmental impacts of post/pre/oxy-combustion integrated with pulverized coal-fired power generation systems at all phases of the energy generation life cycle were evaluated as well [193]. The three processes shared the same infrastructure borders, which involved upstream and downstream power production processes such as coal extraction, energy generation plant building, service, and decommissioning, as well as CO2 capture and compression. Pre-combustion and oxy-fuel technology were found to outperform post-combustion in many environmental impact indicators. In comparison to post-combustion CC, pre- and oxy-combustion used less fuel to generate the same electricity output. Furthermore, pre-combustion CC had the least acidification impact, while the oxyfuel CC has the least eutrophication impact.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Carbon capture linked sustainable development goals
ce:section.ce:para: CC has been widely considered and specifically developed as an effective mitigation measure of climate change. However, there is a critical need to look if the effect is sustainable and for this purpose, an assessment is highly needed to look upon the possibilities for the deployment of CCS that can positively participate in the accomplishment of the UN's SDG's set by 2030. Mikunda et al. have generally discussed the CCS and their relation to the SDGs, with the main focus on their relation to SDG-13 of "Climate action" as a direct outcome, with little emphasis on other goals [194]. Furthermore, CCS enables provisions of decarbonization of the industry and the provision of affordable clean energy utilization, as in SDG-7 of "Affordable and clean energy" as well [195]. Accordingly, it is paramount to map or network the interaction among CCT and different SDGs, given that the goals have high interdependency. Additionally, a technology or a solution might act as an enabler for one goal, and as an inhibiter for another. While evaluating against SDGs, CCS indicates several benefits as CCS is a sort of “indivisible” to SDG-13 in combating climate change. The primary ‘hindering’ factor is the necessity for additional energy per unit of power delivered and the natural effects related to the utilization of some catch frameworks. None of the restraining impacts distinguished had ‘dropping’ cooperation against the SDGs canvassed in this evaluation. CCS is in this way a reasonable alternative to battle environmental change and doesn't forbid the accomplishment of some other SDG. Moreover, the Paris agreement focuses on the need for sustainable development consideration in “low transitions and emissions”.

Similarly, the special report of IPC's on SR1.5 constitutes a primary assessment on the synergies and trade-offs among sustainable development and mitigating options; it also includes the use of CCS in the industrial and energy supply sectors. Furthermore, the IPCC assessment looks into insights for the interaction of CCS with SDGs. However, for the number of SDGs, it has been seen that no assessment seems feasible, as no significant public narrative could be acknowledged [196]. A dedicated and in-depth assessment has been done to further help to sustain and complement the research findings of IPCC. Few studies have mapped the CCS technologies against specific climate and energy DGDs, i.e. SDG-7 and SDG-13 with the aim to improve the accessibility of information relevant to the contribution and achievement of SDG's [197]. The main findings can be summarized as follows:
o CCS has many positive impacts on SDGs; the considerable potential for CCS to decarbonize the industrial and power sectors (SDG-13: Climate action).
o For the provision of sustainable, reliable, and modern energy, CCS plays an extremely important role; it plays a significant part in the decarbonization of the industry not only with the help of direct emission reduction but also ultimately with the help of low carbon power supply (SDG-7: Affordable and clean energy).
o CCS supports inclusive and sustainable economic growth for the productive and full employment of decent work contributing to the decoupling of the financial growth from the environmental degradation, through reduction of associated carbon emission (SDG-8: Decent work and economic growth).
o CCS has the capability of “enabling the infrastructure development”; it has the ability of inclusive and sustainable industrialization, which provides a boost for the innovation system (SDG-9: Industry, innovation, and infrastructure), along with reduced carbon footprint of large cities (SDG-11: Sustainable cities and communities).
o CCS helps also the “Stabilization in the acidification” of the oceans, which is enabled through reduced carbon emissions (SDG-14: Life below water).

However, as with any human-developed technologies, CCS may have some negative interactions with the SDGs. On the basis of SDG-7, meeting the clean and efficient energy targets might be constrained by the additional cost of CCS, hence constraining the affordability target within the same SDG-7. This can be further expanded to SDG-6, clean water and sanitation, availability, and many other cases. The negative impacts of CCS are related to fuel consumption and energy/emissions penalties, and might have a counterfactual impact on the achievements of some other SDGs.

Correspondingly, several knowledge gaps can be identified clearly, in which the present work is an effort toward highlighting and discussing such gaps. Also, the research on the “employment aspects of CCS” in comparison with the low emission technologies needs to be perfromed as well. CCT can contribute to most of the SDGs directly and indirectly, as shown in Table 4 . However, keeping in mind that the SDGs are interrelated, Table 5 and Fig. 8 summarize the direct contributions or impacts of CCT in the achievement of SDGs, which are to be discussed in more detail.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The contribution of carbon capture to sustainable development
ce:section.ce:para: Being mindful of the fact that SDGs are interconnected [198], and they cover the three environmental, economic, and social pillars of sustainable development, as shown in Fig. 9 [199]. This section discusses the contribution of CCT in sustainable development together with related SDGs. Additionally, Fig. 10 summarizes the main benefits of CCT applications to the different sustainable development pillars.

The environmental benefits of CC are clear, as they avoid carbon emissions to the atmosphere, which is the main GHG, as the major mitigation measure for climate change and global warming. According to the IPCC 2014 climate change mitigation report, the total anthropogenic GHGs emissions have reached a benchmark in human history, amounting to 49 ± 4.5 GtCO2-eq/year in 2010 at an annual growth rate of about 1.0 GtCO2-eq/year and reaching total estimated emissions of 2,000 GtCO2-eq throughout 1750–2010 [200]. The CC, due to the avoided carbon emissions in particular and GHGs emissions, in general, will have huge environmental benefits to the whole nature, more specifically to the atmosphere i.e., air and hydrosphere, i.e., water bodies [201,202]. The main contributions of CCT to the different SDGs within the environmental pillar of sustainable development are critically discussed in this section. In Table 6 contribution of CC into the environment with their related SDGs are presented (directly and indirectly), adopted from Refs. [6,78,203–205]. The following section will explain this contribution in detail.

SDG-6 targets providing clean water supplies and sanitation services to people worldwide. About ⅓ the world's population is affected by water scarcity, which is expected to increase along with global warming and erratic climate change. However, since 1990, approximately 2.1 billion people have gained access to water supplies and improved sanitation. Despite this, availability of safe drinking water is a major challenge that requires everyone's attention [206]. The implementation of CC has been viewed as an enabling factor for the utilization of locally available fossil fuel resources, which can help to provide the energy required to drive the production of clean water using the appropriate water treatment processes. Several studies discussing the environmental impacts of CCS deployment through LCA analysis, more specifically for power plants, as a major pollution source [18,207–209].

A significant amount of water is required by fossil fuel power plants for cooling and steam generation purposes, indicated by two key metrics of water consumption and withdrawal [210]. Although the majority of life-cycle water in fossil-fuel power generation is related to the plant infrastructure, upstream for coal mining and extraction, and processing, the added CCS increases all of: water use, consumption and withdrawal considerably [211,212]. Furthermore, the water discharged from power plants can pose some other environmental problems, which can affect the nearby water bodies used as a source of water for water treatment facilities and for the discharge of wastewater. Accordingly, a careful study and balance sheet has to be made considering the benefits-cost analysis of CC with respect to water use.

SDG-12 emphasizes responsible consumption and production practices, with a focus on reducing the stress on natural resources and reducing the waste streams into the environment whether it be land, water, or air. In this goal, an important characteristic is the encouragement of sustainable lifestyles and business practices. The implementation of CC in the energy sector is considered as a direct enabler for the responsible utilization of fossil fuel resources, as well as energy production. CC enables the extraction of energy from fossil fuel resources, while still avoiding severe environmental consequences related to GHG emissions being sequestrated. As such, the ultimate products from the CC-integrated power plant are energy and much lower gaseous emissions. However, this still needs to be carefully considered, as CC still has to utilize considerable energy and materials, such as sorbents and membranes, which end up in waste streams of associated material [213–216].

CCTs are placed in the core of SDG-13 for climate action, aiming to reducing GHG emissions considerably, but without quantitative targets for such reductions. One of the major benefits of CC is also advantageous when addressing the mitigation of climate change and global warming, which result in rising sea level and many other extreme weather events, such as hurricanes, cyclones, floods, and Tsunamies [217–219]. Rising sea levels and other extremes are believed to result from heavily populated coastal cities, which in turn lose their habitat and properties.

Technically, the capture of up to 90% of carbon emissions is feasible for post-combustion CCT iron & steel, cement, steam reforming, and ethylene oxide production processes, according to the IEA. Additionally, slightly lower capture rates are expected for oil refineries, provided that the presence of a number of distributed point sources, as well as site space restrictions for CC equipment [220]. Considering a number of key industrial processes, CCT further shows to be the only technology capable of achieving considerable emission reductions in the near future. Obviously for effective CCS, it is important to have sufficient geological storage capacity, with the availability of various regional storage capacity assessments conducted for China, Europe, and North America [221,222]. There are many significant efforts for communicating CCS as a part of the development of demonstration projects. Project developers have been encouraged due to the generally low awareness of the technology, meaning they can make significant investments in public outreach as well as education activities [223].

The SDG-14 emphasizes preserving the marine environment against pollution and over-exploitation of marine resources, such as overfishing through the sustainable use of such resources, along with strict pollution control measures. This also focuses on minimizing and addressing the impacts of ocean acidification, due to the increased concentration of atmospheric CO2. When the anthropogenic carbon emissions are increased, they are then blamed for the increasing uptake of carbon dioxide by oceans [224]. This in turn, causes the seawater to become much more acidic, while having a detrimental impact on marine life.

CC can have substantial benefits to aquatic life and marine environment, or the hydrosphere. This is simply due to the equilibrium between the atmospheric carbon dioxide and carbonate/bicarbonate/hydrogen system in the water bodies, such as oceans and seas. The equilibrium system can be described by reactions (2–4), with any additional CO2 affecting the equilibrium resulting in more bicarbonate ions according to reaction (5) [225]. The increase in carbonate concentration in the marine environment can result in the precipitation, and hence the change in concentration, of some essential and vital elements in water, such as calcium, magnesium, and many elements (M) to their solid mineral state as shown in reaction (6). This in turn increases the acidity of water bodies, i.e., decreases the water pH, leading to ocean acidification, as well as the elimination of essential elements for the growth of different aquatic species, thereby affecting the aquatic life severely [226,227]. These impacts are to be avoided upon the implementation of CCS, by controlling the concentration of atmospheric CO2.
