Due to the ability to influence the net marine toxicity impact of CC on power plants, it is important to substantiate the impact of the characterization score of hydrogen fluoride reduction by using the flue gas desulphurization [220]. Along with the removal of sulfur dioxide, flue gas desulphurization systems remove other substances present in flue gases, such as particulate matter PM, NOx, hydrogen fluoride, and hydrogen chloride, thereby reducing the Marine Aquatic Ecotoxicity Potential (MAETP) [228,229].

Taking the marine environment into account, the impact of developing CO2 transport infrastructure is highly site-specific. The identification of the environmental impacts of such activity, considering the displacement of seabed material for the shallow pipeline trench, the noise produced while drilling of the carbon dioxide injection well, and additional noise as well as disturbance made by ships, which are involved in realizing the project [230].

The SDG-15 emphasizes life on land. It mainly covers both waste reduction and sustainable management of resources. These resources include soil, wetlands, and forests. The management of resources is made to help in maintaining good biodiversity and healthy ecosystems. This goal also aims in protecting both terrestrial as well as freshwater environments, along with a heavy overlap with the SDG-6, which focuses on clean water and sanitation. There are some impacts that interact with freshwater life, these include: AP, EP, and freshwater aquatic ecotoxicity potential, which affect life on land. These are considered to be indicators that tend to affect water discharged from either the power or industrial plant.

The wider implementation of CC should enable the capture of 10 or 2.8 GtCO2-eq/year by 2050, to limit ambient temperature rise to 1.5 or 2 °C respectively [231,232]. This huge amount was to be released into the atmosphere, which would have resulted in huge pollution and increased CO2 concentrations. Furthermore, the CC will avoid the release of a huge amount of associated pollutants in flue gas, being removed during CC. These gases include SOx, NOx, and PM, which are common in flue gas, more specifically for coal-fired power plants. The IPCC 2005 CC report indicates that CCS system should enable avoiding 342, 704, and 720, kg-CO2/MWh for natural gas NG, pulverized coal (PC), and IGCC power plants, respectively. This will be associated with 0.29, 0.13 kg-SOx/MWh for PC and IGCC power plants respectively [231,233,234]. During CCS, carbon carrying stream is being processed to meet either commercial use or storage specification, as such, the removal of such impurities is considered a must.

However, CC is also associated with higher water usage, both consumption and withdrawal, and wastewater which is released with the potential trace metals and toxic substances [211,229,235–237]. Considering this evidence, it can further be concluded that the CC has both counteracting as well as reinforcing interactions with the objectives set by SDG-15 focusing on life on land. When CC is added, this will considerably cause a reduction in the GWP. In addition to this, the water is used significantly for CC and this can impact habitats. Taking this evidence into account, CC can have both counteracting and reinforcing interactions, as such, the balance needs to be carefully considered.

The main challenge for expanding the CC facilities is the high investment costs. The implementation of CC is expected to add a substantial cost associated with capture, transportation, and storage. The units and processes to capture CO2 in different schemes of post/pre/oxy-combustion, material, and energy used will be at a cost [238,239]. Additionally, there will be an added cost for CO2 transportation, and storage, which increase the overall CCS cost. The estimated costs for CCS are for individual sources, technologies, and site-dependencies, meaning a very wide range of estimations are available. According to the IPCC estimations of 2002, CC costs can vary over the range of $14–71/t-CO2 avoided (CO2 avoided = CO2 emitted without CCS–CO2 emitted with CCS), including $0–5/t-CO2 for transportation and $0.6–8.3/t-CO2 for geological storage [201,231]. The US National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) gives estimations of $43–75/t-CO2 avoided, while the US Electrical Power Research Institute US-EPRI provides $39–63/t-CO2 avoided, including $10/t-CO2 avoided for transportation and storage [234]. Sea level rise susceptibility has been related to substantially decreased construction activities in areas with high climate change vulnerability [240]. The value of properties in coastal areas was found to be highly affected by extreme weather events, which mostly included losing the property itself or significantly reducing its value [241,242]. Table 7 summaries the economic contribution of CCT with the related SDGs, adopted from Refs. [18,194,243–245].

SDG-7 aims to provide affordable and clean energy. The key objective for this goal includes increased energy efficiency, accelerating the deployment of renewable energy, and expanding access to energy [246–248]. This goal is connected to several other goals, including good health and well-being, economic growth, and climate action. The assumptions made on the affordability of a specific power generation technology can further be informed by an assessment of the levelized cost of electricity (LCOE). LCOE considers capital and operating expenditures CAPEX and OPEX, investments, and discount rate. CCS increases the cost of electricity production, along with these costs, presumably passed on to the customer to the detriment of affordability [220]. Considering reliability with this goal, interpretation is related to power systems meeting the power demand consistently. Fossil fuel power generation is considered reliable and dependable when compared to most of the renewable energy resources currently in place, with wind and solar energy having capacity factors of only 20–40% [249]. Accordingly, CC tends to improve the sustainability of a reliable power supply for the long-term basis at an increased, but still competitive cost. Applying CC both has enabling and counteracting relations to this goal [249].

ce:section.ce:section-title: SDG-8 Decent work and economic growth
ce:section.ce:para: SDG-8 is focusing on decent work and economic growth. This goal covers different elements of economic growth, resource efficiency, and improved productivity, decoupling economic growth from environmental degradation and promoting decent work. The economics of CC has been widely studied in the Stern Review [250–252], the Garnaut Review for the Australian Commonwealth [253], and the International Energy Agency IEA [254]. The stern review estimates an investment of about $250 bn/year to be required by 2030 to achieve the IPCC goals. This in turn, will result in an avoided loss of about 5–20% of the global product from there on out. The Garnaut Review provides CCS cost of about 0.8% of the Australian gross national product (GNP) initially, dropping later to about 0.0–0.2% by 2050. In turn, this will result in about 0.2% of the GNP starting from 2050 onwards. Similarly, the IEA provides an estimate of about $4.1 tn over 20 years, resulting in annual savings of $7 tn in fuel cost alone.

The preceding discussion shows the huge investments to be put into CC worldwide and the estimated return. By 2020, there were about 65 large-scale CCS projects, with 38 in the Americas, 13 in Europe, 10 in the Asia Pacific, and 3 in the Middle East with a total capacity of 40 mt-CO2/year [255]. This capacity is expected to increase up to 5,635 mt-CO2/year from about 2,000 CCS facilities by 2050 [256]. This huge investment and increased number of facilities would result in more economic developments and expansion in existing power plants and industrial sites to accommodate for CCS facilities, as well as the construction of stand-alone facilities. Furthermore, investments in fossil resources can witness an increase given the overcome of the main challenges to expand utilization of these resources, i.e., carbon emissions, hence higher economic growth may be enabled.

There is very little literature that covers the economic impacts of the deployment of CC and this further limits evidence-based conclusions. Considering CC applications, there is no such particular evidence that has been identified related to the potential economic impacts [257]. Generally, the consensus on the relationship possessed by energy costs and economic growth is that when the energy costs go high, economic growth is inhibited [258]. For this reason, having CC available is considered an option that should be positive for economic growth, although it may result in having all important decarbonization options available for cost-optimized selection in comparison to any intrinsic characteristic of CC itself.

Considering the CC application in industries, it can be said that there is no such evidence that has been identified, which explains explicitly the impact on economic growth. When the capture technology is applied to industrial sites, then it would represent a substantial investment that can be partially waved by energy and emission incentives. Nevertheless, there are many energy-intensive products (such as cement, steel) for which there are no substitutes available for many applications. Therefore, it becomes much simpler to predict how the increase in CC–driven cost would influence demand for the products [259]. Additionally, resource efficiency, such as economic productivity is much likely to be affected positively by the energy price reduction which is incurred by CC. Improving the resource efficiency in the energy sector would require the production of useable final energy products from a specific raw materials input [259,260].

The SDG-9 mainly targets sustainable infrastructure development, upgrades in industry, sustainable industrialization, and also, research and innovation which seem much likely to the CC. Economic sustainability is distinct from environmental sustainability. This refers to if an economic activity can be continued over the long term or not. In relation to CC, the question of finite resources and the concept of lock-in becomes relevant potentially.

The goal has some other targets, which emphasize raising the share of employment and growth domestic product (GDP). Some studies are made on the economic impacts of CCS. These studies observe a clear difference in the impact between sectors, but their support to increase the industry share is shown [261]. One of the more interesting benefits of CC is in the technology innovation and associated research & development (R&D) activities. Given the technical and economical challenges associated with CC and the crucial need for the innovative processes of high efficiency and low cost, many innovative technologies, processes, and materials are expected to be developed. These innovative solutions might find further applications in many other fields, hence provide additional economic benefits and returns.

SDG-11 targets cover a large number of core issues that are relevant to cities and communities and this further includes disaster resilience, access to safe and affordable basic services, quality of life issues, and environmental impact. To consider the environmental impact of a city, it is important to include the LCA of these inputs. CC has both positive and negative environmental implications. The most tangible outcome of CC is to reduce GHG emissions by 60–80% [18]. This can make a substantial contribution by reducing the climate change associated with energy and products used by different cities and communities.

The environmental and economic aspects of CC have been always the main focus for studies assessing and evaluating the different impacts and delivered benefits. However, CC delivers as well more societal and social benefits. Firstly, due to improved air quality and reduced air pollution, human health is improved, resulting in a healthier society and community. The second major benefit is job creation, due to the huge investment in CC projects, as well as enabled fossil energy projects, which help to reduce unemployment and increase human welfare. The third major benefit is the mitigation of climate change, and hence mitigation of global temperature rises that result in sea level rise and sinking of coastal areas. According to the IPCC and IEA, there is a need to establish up to 2,000 CCS facilities by 2050 to mitigate the climate change effects of carbon emissions [200,262,263]. It is estimated that the construction and operation of such a number of CCS facilities will help to create up to 100,000 employees by 2050, with more jobs associated with material and equipment supply, logistics, professional services, and many others. This will in turn, decrease the unemployment rate, along with the associated social and societal problems, thereby increasing human welfare.

SDG-3 is about good health and well-being and majorly focuses on human health. This goal addresses a large number of health and well-being issues, which include neonatal, maternal mortality, disease epidemics, substance abuse, hazardous pollution, road accidents and injuries, and sexual health. Air pollution in general, including emissions from fossil fuels, such as COx, SOx, NOx, and PM have strongly related to many health problems, especially those associated with the respiratory system [264,265]. CC essentially removes most, if not all, of air pollutants as explained earlier as part of the environmental benefits of CCS. In Shanghai, China, it has been estimated that the low-carbon energy policy to reduce ambient air pollution car resulted in reducing the PM-related avoidable deaths by 2,804–8,249 and 9,870–23,100 in 2010 and 2020, respectively [266]. In China, a recent study has indicated that carbon and pollution control policies can provide a benefit of reducing nationwide mortalities related to PM and O3 by about 23% or 289,000 in most strict scenarios between 2015 and 2030 [267].

Implementing CC face several challenges and barriers [268–272]. These barriers are various and require full collaboration among the different stakeholders and shareholders in different energy utilization sectors such as heat and power, transportation, and industry. Table 8 presents the different barriers that face CC implimentation and their linkage to the related SDGs. The barriers are mainly economic, technical, and administrative in nature. The economic barriers are related to funding or finicial support required for R&D, support to wave the currently high cost of CC, and govermental incentives to CC. The technical bariers are related to capture efficiency, material and process development among many others. The administrative barriers are related to leglization and policies to encourage and support R&D and implementation of CC.

In the recent years the movement towards the circular economy was raised. Circular economy aims at regenerating or reusing resources to produce new products. This to replace the conventional linear economy which starts from utilizing resources to products, which ends up as a waste that has to be properly managed. CC would have the capability to support this movement. Whereby circular economy focusing on turning goods at end of their service life into resources to other products [273], which can be achieved through the carbon capture and utilization CCU. In addition, the carbon capture has several contributions into the circular economy, which summarized and linked to the related SDGs in Table 9 . In CCU, the carbon emissions results from the utilization of fossil resources to produce fuels is turned back into fuels or chemical commodities in a circular economy approach.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Novel indicators for pre-combustion carbon capture and sustainable development
ce:section.ce:para: Based on the discussion above, a set of indicators was developed to ensure that pre-combustion CC technology contributes to all SDGs, therefore, has a balance between the three pillars (economic, social, and environment) of sustainable development. The development of indicators was constructed based on a literature review and related guidelines [274–276]. The pre-combustion CC has been chosen specifically for its higher overall merits compared to other CC approaches, as discussed earlier and summarized in Table 1.

Most of the previous approaches used for assessing the CC impacts are focusing on measuring the environmental impact or social impact, using the LCA and social impact assessment (SIA). While, LCA is a good tool to analysis the environmental and social impacts of the products [277,278], it does not cover some aspects such as risk management, communications with stakeholder, data management, etc. The devleoped indicators for each SDG are shown in Table 10 . Moreover, the proposed indicators include those recommended in LCA as one of the current proposed indicators. These make the proposed indicators unique in their position, by including both technical and business indicators. Which would help the different stakeholders to ensure the positive contribution of the CC project in achieving the SDGs. In addition, the proposed indicators are unique in their nature as they can integrate the SDGs within the Key Performance Indicator (KPI).

The proposed indicators covered all the SDGs and unlike the previous indicators, which were more technicality-oriented, the proposed indicators in the current work look at CC as a project with more focus on sustainable management. The proposed indicators could work as a guideline for the different stakeholders within the industry to ensure that CCT benefits are maximized, and the possible trade-off impacts are minimized. These indicators ensure that the decision-makers are aware of the different measures, policies, analyses, and actions that should be taken to avoid any possible trade-off impact on SDGs due to CC. Moreover, the proposed indicators provide a framework for the different stakeholders to develop strategies and allocate resources. They also measure the progress toward the attainment of sustainable development and SDGs.

These indicators can lead to increased transparency and get the required feedback from the different stakeholders. Another important role of the proposed indicators is to provide a better means and basis of comparison between the different CCTs, from the perspective of sustainable development and SDGs. Similar to other indicators, they play a constructive role in recognizing problems, identifying trends, and contributing to the process of priority setting. One significant role of the proposed indicators is to help building knowledge and capacity, and provide a platform to communicate the complex issues of sustainable development and SDGs. At the beginning of each section, the relevant indicators were provided to ease the reading and discussion of the indicators. Table 10 summarizes the different SDGs, along with the developed indicators used to assess the contribution of CC to each goal. In the following discussions, power plants utilizing fossil fuel resources have been considered as typical carbon emissions sources, with CC being integrated into their operation.

Besides, the main role of the proposed indicators in assisting and maximizing the achievement of the SDGs, they have several advantages [279,280] such as: providing information for the decision makers, enhancing and benchmark sustainability performance, improve risk management, enhancing data management and reporting practices, improving resource allocation and reduce the expenses, improve enviroemtnal perfomanrace, reduce social impact, and improve communications with stakeholder. Also one of advantages of the proposed indicators that they are applicable to both small and large scale industry. However, the cost and the resources required for the implementation wouldvary. The proposed indicators would help the policy makers and stakeholders in maximizing the benefits of the CC in achieving the different SDGs and minimizing the trade off, therefore, it would help them in supporting the implementation of the CC in both small and large scale industries.

However, implementing and taking into the consideration the proposed indicators by the stakeholder have some limitations. The main limitation is coming from the cost and time that would be involved in such implementation [281]. Nevertheless, with the proper management of the financial resources and looking to long term benefits, this limitation could be overcome [282]. Another limitation or barrier might be involved in the implementation of the proposed indicators is the social resistance [283]. These barriers can be overcome by engaging the local community in the early stage of the project and throughout the different stages and also the intensive share the benefits with the different stakeholder would help to reduce the social resistance [284,285]. Furthermore, the proposed indicators would increase the workload of the sustainable development (social, economic and environment).
In Table 11 , the indicators were grouped based on their related benefits (some indictors can be categorized under more than one benefits).

Power plants consider that fossil fuels are still maintained as the primary energy sources involving mining activities that give benefits to the local community, in terms of getting revenue and improving quality of life. However, one important factor that must be considered is that the initial capital expenditure for such projects is still high due to the addition of CC [286]. Whenever this matter is not the constraint of the implementation of the project, the SDG-1 can be aligned, and most indicators of the SDG-1 can be easily expected.

Funding is required to provide essential services and developing infrastructure. Governments make revenues required through taxes in exchange for the provided services, with proper taxation process to make this process efficient [287]. Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) tend to make more employment that lifts out people from poverty [288]. In the private sector, job creation has been the main driver in the fight against poverty. MSMEs contribute significantly to the employment creation process. Four out of five new jobs in the formal sector were created by MSMEs, while markets were emerging and this is around 90% of the total employment [289].

Labor productivity is increased through better nutrition, better health, and higher education levels, and also enhances the non-farming employment opportunities. There should be policies that encourage productivity and investment along with social protection interventions, targeting nutrition, health, and education to help smallholders to achieve a higher income generation [290]. The utilities price is one critical aspect of SDGs, therefore it important to ensure that tariff is dropping down.

To boost the achievement of SDG-2, the policy that is made should be in favor of poor people or smallholders. Related to this point, the selection of land for the construction of projects should be taken carefully, especially in the productive fertile agricultural area. The priority of the recommended location for projects should be in the nonarable land so that it would not disturb and thus reduce the productivity of smallholders. The capacity of the local community should also be empowered through the creation of local community partnerships and collaboration. There should be disaster risk investigation and analysis, which could be spelled out in the form of risk management policy. The construction and operation of the power plant may involve the utilization and production of a hazardous material as well, so the balance of this hazardous material should be recorded.

A fundamental role is played by safe water and sanitation in improving the nutritional outcomes. When there is a lack of clean water and appropriate sanitation services, this can result in diarrhea. If these conditions remain constant, this can then result in under-nutrition. Diarrhea, due to the absence of appropriate sanitation service, is considered to be one of the primary causes of child deaths below age 5 in developing countries [291].

It is an industry-standard that any activity should be explicitly indicated by hazard identification and hazard operability analysis and assessment. This is followed by health, safety, and environmental policies used as a reference or guideline for employees during different project phases of commissioning, operation, and maintenance. Job safety analysis and work permit procedures should be well documented as a part of the workflow, in addition to policies to maintain all employees in good health and well-being condition, such as pollution control measures. The risk assessment includes an understanding of both exposures, as well as effects that are required to characterize the risk for different situations [292–294]. The LCA can be used to measure the human toxicity potential (HTP), particulate matter (PM), photochemical ozone creation potential of pre-combustion CC. The measuring should follow the different guideline provide by a reputable organization, such as ISO 14040 [295], to reduce the uncertainty and increases the acceptance of the results.

The power plant projects should prepare the provision of the employee carrier roadmap, complete with all required courses and assessment tools that can be used to know and test the skill level of employees. At each level, there should be recommended course lists, a timeline to take the courses, and the corresponding examination. Every employee should have equal opportunity in pursuing his/her training program to get a higher level of the carrier. Labor recruitment requirements should include strict policy not to admit child labor regarding age, as well as the prohibition of a child to work in any hazardous industry. Child labor is a type of economical abuse, and is a rising issue globally. It is important to take measures to prevent child labor and one of the important measures is education.

Business and management schools have a critical role in shaping the mindsets of future business leaders [296]. Among the major responsibilities are increasing welfare and expanding education services to the whole community. The issue related to shaping education is a matter of concern, as changing educational policies should go hand-in-hand with the contemporary world's needs. Such kinds of changes implemented can result in children being ousted from school [297]. In addition to the focus on enabling environment for investment and market integration, policies should also focus on education and health.

Generally, the power industry does not have a considerable effect on gender equality. However, it may have indirect and nonspecific effects, such as the possibility of promoting growth and development, which in turn may require increased options and opportunities for women's involvement in power projects. Whenever it is required to deliver SDG-5, it could begin with this promotion of the growth and development of women. Ensuring that woman fully and equally involved in decision process would be improve would reduce many issue that related to gender quality [298].

Power plants in general, and those with CC, in particular, should not be located in water scarcity areas, due to high water consumption and withdrawal requirements, which may become an issue and negatively affect SDG-6 realization. Water and wastewater management are required for this situation where the corresponding scope includes water pollution, water use reduction, wastewater minimization, etc. [299,300]. Furthermore, water quality, freshwater aquatic ecotoxicity potential (FAETP), eutrophication potential (EP) before and after project implementation should be monitored as well, this can be achived using LCA or EIA.

The aim of pre-combustion CC is to produce clean fuel or hydrogen, as a direct contribution to SDG-7. This in turn, provides reasonable and sustainable clean energy that can be accessed by more people. This technology innovation aims to reduce much of the carbon emissions into the atmosphere to meet the universal goal of controlling global warming and climate change. Besides energy-related parameters, some additional indicators can be added to monitor and manage the performance of the technology implementation, such as the educational program for enhancing the awareness of energy usage, total investment to support the water initiatives, total investment for R&D in clean water, and cost of energy before and after the implementation of CC based coal IGCC power plant technology. Levelized cost of energy (LCOE) and avoided CO2 cost should help to conduct an economic assessment [257].

ce:section.ce:section-title: SDG-8 Decent work and economic growth
ce:section.ce:para: The implementation of CC in the power plant is expected to enable positive community growth in the area of mining, employees involved in the transportation, and the community around the power plant. Community quality of life improvements should be created, which could be facilitated by the project policies. Some indicators could be set up and targeted, completed with the monitoring tools for monitoring and continuous improvement. These indicators include compensation of the resources which are used during: project execution and facility operation and maintenance, local procurement of goods and services, number of housing for temporary employees, and incentives given to employees.

When a proper allocation of financial risks and return on investment are performed, it tends to enable the public and private sectors to earn returns commensurate to the risks taken through the 3Ts (Tariffs, Taxes, and Transfers) [301]. Additionally, the rise in local investments remains the key source to closing the financing gap in many projects. Governments can apply a range of policies to improve the financial viability of utilities, recover the investment costs, and provide an income stream for improving the risk-return profile. These investments, which are related to utilities include [302]: pollution taxes, tariffs for utilities, abstraction charges, public good charges, value capture mechanisms; and payments for ecosystem services [303].

Since the beginning of CCimplementation, management should prepare the roadmap of related industry innovations, and the development of infrastructure for the surrounding community to get better living standards. This matter should be matched with local community potential for their sustainable development, while maintaining the consideration to reduce carbon emission and greenhouse effects. The social, economic and environmental benifits should take place in the local community with clear quantitative indicators, such as GHG emissions, level of compliance to government policies, number of convening powers employed, and total value-added created.

It is important to have a more systematic and rational approach in order to plan sustainably. This need brought attention to Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA). This is said to be a proactive method (or technique) that informs decision-makers of the possible impacts of their future actions. EIA tends to predict as well as minimize considerable environmental impacts before the implementation of the project. Usually, an EIA is said to form an integral part of the project feasibility study, planning and design, and also, the approval process [304,305]. EIA calculates direct, indirect, and induced aspects of a projects. The EIA further assumes that there will be an increase in employment which can be a result of a project, without either any wage or any price effects. This is said to be possible because previously, it was argued that resources that are unused or underused will become employed.

The Social Impact Assessment (SIA) has guidelines and principles that consider social impact as consequences to human populations [306]. These consequences alter how people live, work, and organize relative to one another. Social consequences can be both either positive or negative. The purpose of the SIA is to analyze, monitor and manage such consequences, be it intended or unintended [306].

The implementation strategy and policy of the power plant project should incorporate the actionable plan to elevate the lives of marginalized local communities to achieve the overall goals of sustainability. The project management should prepare some training programs for marginalized populations and also facilitate financing alternatives to realize prospective activities giving a better life for them. Project management or companies should consider the wage disparities among working groups and also levels of diversity and inclusion. This should be perfromed to support the initiatives for decreasing inequalities based on gender, race, wages, or any other relevant reason [307].

Sustainable cities and surrounding communities should be considered in the project implementation of CC-based power plants. Some factors that should be considered and prepared are: disaster resilience plans, utility system models, and resource sustainability policies. The utilization of fossil fuels should be considered as a transitional phase during the driving of the increasing use of renewable energy resources. Whenever possible, the implementation of a microgrid or hybrid renewable energy system, including a battery system, may be better, as it can be considered as one performance indicator. Fossil-biomass cofiring might be possible as one alternative to introducing renewable energy or biofuel into conventional thermal power plants. Regarding the sustainable city, the generated waste should be included in the consideration for policy development. Resource efficiency is said to be a part of sustainable development. In the UK, over recent years, this has become embodied in governmental legislation, with different countries have similar programs [308].

Sustainable development can be defined as a dynamic process that tends to enable all people to know or realize their potential. This, at the same time, will protect and enhance the life support systems on Earth [309]. This is viewed as the feasibility of the sustainable development concept, which ranges from unrealistic, to unfeasible, to possible.

The project management team should take the responsibility for the resources and materials consumed during project and facility operation and maintenance, as well as the performance of the system in converting the input materials and energy resources into useful energy. This also includes system energy efficiency and its related pollution and waste generated. Reporting and tracking some indicators are also important, including their types of short-term and long-term pollution of air, water, and land [310]. The energy produced, energy efficiency, and all generated waste should be reported and tracked as important indicators.

Carbon capture is at the core of the climate problem abatement plan, as such can substantially reduce GHG emissions to avoid global warming and other climate changes. To strengthen and enhance the performance in reducing environmental impacts, other strategic actions should be planned and some indicators should be set up, monitored, and tracked. These include all types of pollution, the rate of the supply chain emission, portions of projects located in the area with emissions reduction potential, number of researches directed toward climate change solutions, and level of engagement in industrial climate dialogues as well. CCS/CCU would require the development of rules to manage risks and support policies for facilitating investment. Accordingly, legal and regulatory understanding are important factors that could promote or hinder CCS implementation [311].

The CC project should assess the environmental and social impacts, tracking and reporting all water-related pollution. Wherever the location of the project is on the coastline, then marine ecotoxicity should be measured using an LCA tool. Many methods can generate the result of aquatic ecotoxicity impact; these methods include: EDIP 97, CML2001, IMPACT2002+, and TRACI [312]. The ecotoxicity has shown to increase in the new installations and retrofit of CC units in power plants in comparison to the no CC scenario, as heavy metals from the flue gas are released to the soil and water, instead of air [313].

As a part of project implementation plans, there should be an EIA, a comprehensive baseline for EIA, assessment of projects located in brownfields and previously developed land, research initiative, and landscape planning related to life on land, which measure the impact on biodiversity and ecosystem. Aside from this, total resources required and total land occupied should be identified. Furthermore, freshwater aquatic ecotoxicity potential (FAETP) and eutrophication potential (EP) should be measured using the LCA tool. These parameters should be clearly defined and monitored to verify the impact of the project on the surrounding life on land. The pre-combustion CC tends to reduce the GWP by 64 and 78% for natural gas- and coal-based power plants [314]. Nevertheless, such CC results in increased freshwater eutrophication impact and other toxicity categories in comparison to conventional power plants.

ce:section.ce:section-title: SDG-16 Peace, justice, and strong institution
ce:section.ce:para: To run the CC-based power plant successfully with peace and justice and to make the project or company a strong institution, there should be a development of robust anti-bribery management systems. In the project planning phase, management should encourage stakeholders to get involved to let them know well about the overall plan for the success of project implementation. Furthermore, compliance with the project's regulation and disclosure of information should be well kept and enforced. The regulatory requirements tend to provide the minimum assurance level at which stakeholders are not subjected to pre-identified harm. Attempts to cover up non-conformities with regulatory bodies that can result in a breakdown of credibility should be prohibited. Stakeholders, including customers and employees, fairly assume that an organization should be aware of governing necessities and are competent in meeting different obligations. For listed companies, disclosing the information is said to be a legal obligation. This directly influences transparency and pricing efficiency (that is an important basis for which investments decisions are made by the investors) on the securities market. Alongside this, it also serves as the legitimate basis of its ideologies of honesty, fairness, and impartialness.

The success of the CC project implementation also depends on other parties in the form of partnership. The collaboration required in the project includes working with other industrial, governmental, and local entities or authorities. In addition to this collaboration, the project management should allocate the financial resources and consider the incorporation and alignment of SDGs in the company policies. Related indicators should also be defined and monitored carefully. Without considering the size of the industry, all companies can contribute to the SDGs, as part of their sustainable development targets. On one hand, while the scope and scale of the global goals are unprecedented, then, there can be some fundamental ways in which any business can contribute, and these ways remain unchanged. Companies are being asked, by the UN Global Compact, to do business responsibly and to pursue the opportunities for solving the challenges using business innovation and collaborations [315].

The first and foremost step is to adopt accountable business practices and commit to sustainability in their operations. However, there can be situations or global challenges which can be tough and cannot be faced or solved by one company or sector alone. Most of the time, in such situations, partnerships and working in partnership help a lot and result in a greater impact. It has its reach and exceptional competencies to become a prevailing source of innovation. Moreover, the business community can work side by side with the public sector for developing cohesive solutions to global challenges [316].

Carbon capture CC technologies in general, and pre-combustion CC, in particular, is viewed as an effective tool to significantly reduce global greenhouse gases (GHGs) emissions, which are at the heart of the global response to global warming and climate change challenges. Pre-combustion has shown to have an intermediate level of merits and demerits among different CCTs, making it an optimum candidate for CC. Building a new or retrofitting old power plant with CC, as one of the main sources of carbon emissions, and a good model for other carbon emissions sources is gaining huge environmental, economic, and social potential, as the main sustainable development pillars.

In the current work, CC have been evaluated and assessed regarding their effectiveness in reaching the United Nations’ (UN) Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The role of CC in achieving the SDGs was discussed and elaborated. The major contribution is coming from CC ability in reducing the climate change impact (SDG-13) and providing cleaner source of energy (SDG-7). In addition, the relations between circular economy and CC was presented together with the related SDGs. Additionally, the barriers facing the implementation of the CC with relevant SDGs were introduced. A total of 87 indicators have been identified for the 17 SDGs within this study, providing sustainability guidelines for different stakeholders. The provided indicators ensured that all possible trade-off impacts of the pre-combustion CC with all SDGs have been reduced or even eliminated, while also providing a set of balance between the three pillars of sustainable development. The developed indictors provide a guideline for decision-makers and policy-makers to maximize the benefits of the project. The other benefits are: providing information for the decision-makers, enhance and benchmark sustainability performance, improve risk management, enhance data management and reporting practices, improve resource allocation and reduce the expenses, improve enviroemtnal perfomanrace, reduce social impact, and improve communications with stakeholder. .
